exampleContent.title: Table Exercise Examples
exampleContent.description: Learn how to complete tables, charts, and organize information systematically
learningPoints: Read column and row headers carefully
Look for patterns in the data
Use logic to determine missing information
Check that your answers make sense in context

sections.title: Simple Data Tables
sections.description: Learn to complete basic information tables with missing data

examples.title: Animal Characteristics Table
examples.explanation: Rabbits are herbivores, so they eat plants. This logical connection helps us fill in the missing information.
examples.strategy: Think about what you know about each animal's natural diet and habitat.

examples.title: Math Addition Table
examples.explanation: This is an addition table where you add the number in the first column to the number in the top row.
examples.strategy: Look for the mathematical pattern to determine missing values.

sections.title: Classification Tables
sections.description: Learn to organize items into categories using tables

examples.title: Food Groups Table
examples.explanation: Items are organized by their food group classification.
examples.strategy: Think about the characteristics that define each category.

sections.title: Pattern Completion Tables
sections.description: Learn to identify and continue patterns in table format

examples.title: Number Pattern Table
examples.explanation: This table shows even numbers. Each position contains a number that is 2 times the position number.
examples.strategy: Look for mathematical relationships between position and value.

exercises.instruction: Complete the missing information in this animal table.
exercises.explanation: Birds have 2 legs, and fish live in water with no legs.
3 × 3 = 9 and 4 × 4 = 16. Multiply the row number by the column number.

exercises.instruction: Fill in the missing food items in their correct categories.
exercises.explanation: Banana is a fruit and Lettuce is a vegetable.

exercises.instruction: Complete this pattern table showing doubles.
exercises.explanation: Double of 3 is 6, and double of 5 is 10. Each number is multiplied by 2.
